Aw man thatâ€™s rough. Itâ€™s hard with autoimmune diseases because you can test normal and still have them. I had other symptoms when I was in college that I didnâ€™t have when I was diagnosed. My numbers were normal then, but my doc said itâ€™s possible that I still had it anyway even then. I really empathize. I canâ€™t even remember how many medical tests I had when I was in college. No one knew what was wrong with me and it seemed like no one cared to connect the dots. They all just thought I was crazy, which - I mean - yeah I was, and that was the problem. It was medically induced. ğŸ˜‘ I really wish you the best of luck. Maybe try cutting sodium if thatâ€™s relevant to your current diet at all. I switched to Himalayan salt and use less of it. The paleo diet has been really good for me. Even my head feels clearer.

I did! There are so many possible symptoms because the thyroid is connected to everything. When I went to the doc, it was because I started having issues breathing just resting. My resting heart rate was 140 BPM. The extra thyroid hormones were making my heart work like I was constantly running. That caused muscle tension because my body really thought I was working out all the time. It was wild. You can imagine how that constant physical stress would affect the mind. 

Now Iâ€™m on thyroid meds (they did cause some weight gain at first but it leveled out and I was able to lose it once I could exercise again), and Iâ€™ve been able to reduce the dosage by switching to a diet with no dairy, no processed foods, and only occasional meat. I feel so much better.

That actually ended up being a symptom of hyperthyroidism for me, which also involves heightened anxiety as a symptom (making everything worse). Iâ€™d recommend a doc for sure. Iâ€™ve felt much better since sorting the physical medical stuff out. Easier to manage the mental. Good luck to you. â¤ï¸

Edited to add: I also noticed that the pulse was worse after high sodium foods, which was also connected to the thyroid issue. I tried eating ramen one evening and seriously almost went to the ER. I probably should have because theyâ€™d have diagnosed my hyperthyroidism 2 months earlier than when I finally went. My hyperthyroidism is due to Gravesâ€™ disease which is an autoimmune condition.

I have attachment issues (fearful avoidant attachment style) because of mental/emotional abuse from my family. I never recognized it as abuse until therapy. Thatâ€™s why the idea of being close to people upset me. Even if that doesnâ€™t resonate with you, I would still suggest trying therapy. Itâ€™s one of my favorite things to do every week. For me, I have a fearful avoidant attachment style. OP, feel free to PM me if youâ€™d like. That style means that you want to be close to people but youâ€™re afraid and push them away. Iâ€™m not over it yet but Iâ€™ve made great progress. I lost 90 pounds, but the weight loss still didnâ€™t make me feel able to be intimate with anyone. Instead of being self conscious about my weight Iâ€™m now self conscious about my loose skin, stretch marks, and saggy breasts. ğŸ˜” 

Whatâ€™s helped me the most honestly was starting to go to therapy with a therapist that specializes in relationships, body image, and self-worth. Sheâ€™s a dance movement therapist too, which doesnâ€™t exactly mean dancing haha. Itâ€™s all about connecting body to mind to feel at peace with yourself. We do yoga, breathing exercises, and free movement together around the typical talk therapy that takes the most of our time together. I have felt more confident and free than I have my whole life. Iâ€™m learning to love myself, and learning so much about my past and how I got here. 

Iâ€™m 29F, still a virgin, but I feel so close to being ready to be with someone. Iâ€™ve been talking to someone for 3 months now and weâ€™re going to meet next week. We were going to meet last month and I freaked. I almost ghosted him. Instead, I took my therapistâ€™s advice and was honest with what I needed. He was great about it and I actually feel ready now. Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll be super awkward in person hahaha but Iâ€™m optimistic that the tools Iâ€™ve developed will get me through it. 

So my main advice is therapy! If you have a physical ailment, you get help. The same should be accepted and encouraged for our mental health. Youâ€™re not crazy. You might just have some unresolved trauma or bad habits that youâ€™ve learned to protect yourself, and there are professionals that can help you overcome them. ğŸ˜Š
